entry.title: Pashinyan rebukes Putin and calls November 9 agreement ‚Äúwatered down‚Äù

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan rebukes Putin and calls November 9 agreement ‚Äúwatered down‚Äù
media:group.media:description:
üìçPashinyan says November 9 agreement "watered down", blames Russian peacekeepers for not protecting Nagorno-Karabakh population. üìçA Russian army deserter who fled to Armenia was arrested and extradited, apparently without the permission of Armenian authorities. üìçExtravagant Christmas tree lighting in Republic Square raises questions about optics amid the loss of Nagorno-Karabakh. üìçListen to an interview with new Canadian Ambassador to Armenia Andrew Turner on the two nations‚Äô partnership and priorities. Link: https://youtu.be/FlOl1J24opI

entry.title: No Mud, No Lotus: #mindfulleaders with Larisa Hovhannisyan #shorts

media:group.media:title: No Mud, No Lotus: #mindfulleaders with Larisa Hovhannisyan #shorts
media:group.media:description:
Watch full interview: https://youtu.be/yQfg2h0gYtg In this episode, we explore the life of Larisa Hovannisian, from her childhood and education in Yerevan, Moscow, Wisconsin, and Phoenix to her life as the founder and CEO of Teach for Armenia. We explore important topics such as her family roots, her journey in establishing Teach for Armenia, and the challenges and drives that helped her become a successful social entrepreneur. Finally, Larisa shares her view on the importance of faith, self-belief, life purpose, parenthood, social-emotional learning, and the role of education today.
About Larisa Hovannisian Larisa Hovannisian is the founder and CEO of Teach for Armenia, a social impact organization dedicated to catalyzing impact-driven leaders addressing educational inequity for all children in Armenia and formerly in Artsakh. She holds a double degree in International Business and French, a minor in Graphic Design from St. Norbert College in De Pere, Wisconsin, and a master‚Äôs degree in special education from Arizona State University. As an educational activist, Larisa was nationally recognized by the Armenian government in 2016 for her contribution to the advancement of Armenia through her work with Teach for Armenia.

media:group.media:description:
üìçLife of Armenia‚Äôs vital Metsamor Nuclear Plant‚Äôs will be extended through 2036 per a deal signed with the Russian state nuclear agency Rosatom. üìçPrime Minister Pashinyan emphasized peace remains a priority for the Armenian government while hinting that Azerbaijan has been standing in the way of progress. üìçCivilNet Syunik's journalist Armine Simonyan awarded for her report on the resettlement of displaced people from Artsakh in the border village of Tegh. Link to her winning report: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lXI9DzI6T-A üìçInterview with international lawyer Dr. Raffi Philllipe Kalfayan on the objectives behind Azerbaijan‚Äôs detainment of Artsakh's leaders and the violation of their rights. Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P5GutCuQUZc

entry.title: Canada in Armenia: A Talk with the First Resident Ambassador

media:group.media:title: Canada in Armenia: A Talk with the First Resident Ambassador
media:group.media:description:
CivilNet host Patrick Elliott interviews recently appointed Canadian Ambassador to Armenia Andrew Turner. They discuss Canada's priorities and partnership with Armenia, exploring ways to strengthen bilateral cooperation across sectors from investment to peacebuilding. Listeners will gain insight into Canada's vision for the region and its commitment to supporting Armenia's continued development and security.

entry.title: Armenian POWs: Baku‚Äôs Objectives and International Law

media:group.media:title: Armenian POWs: Baku‚Äôs Objectives and International Law
media:group.media:description:
Dr. Raffi Philllipe Kalfayan is a lawyer in international public law, an associate researcher in Paris Pantheon Assas University and the former Secretary General of the International Federation of Human Rights. In this conversation with CivilNet, he shares his professional insights about the legal intricacies of the detention of military and political leaders from Artsakh. He discusses the serious allegations made against these prisoners of war, the violation of their rights, the motivations behind Azerbaijan's actions, and the international community's role in influencing their release.
